awd_titl_txt: Using a Uniform Sample of Sub-Galactic-Scale Binary Active Galactic Nuclei to Understand Changes in Galaxies Over Time Caused by Galaxy Merging
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1

One of the fundamental predictions of the cold dark matter cosmology is that galaxies grow through a series of major and minor mergers with other galaxies. By studying galaxy mergers through detailed observations and theoretical models, we can understand galaxy changes over time in general. Significant progress has been made in the past two decades, but the problem is far from solved. The key physical processes of galaxy merging remain poorly understood. In particular, simulations make predictions that until now have been difficult to identify because of observational challenges, hindering direct comparison between observation and simulation. This proposal seeks to advance our understanding of galaxy changes caused by mergers by eliminating the observational obstacles and characterizing the frequency of binary black holes at small physical scales.

Part 2

This proposal will identify, confirm, and characterize a sample of kiloparsec-scale binary Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs). For the first time, the binaries will be identified systematically using high-resolution deep radio and optical surveys in a 275 square degree field. This search will increase the current sample of kiloparsec-scale binary AGNs by an order-of-magnitude. Unbiased by dust-obscuration, the sample will cover a range of host galaxy properties and black-hole-accretion modes. By comparing the uniformly selected binary AGNs with matched control samples, the team will investigate a number of outstanding questions in the merger paradigm of galaxy formation and change: Can mergers trigger and synchronize black hole accretion? What is the origin of the two-accretion/feedback modes (radiative-mode vs. jet-mode)? Can AGN feedback significantly affect the star formation activity on a short timescale (~1,000,000 years)? How frequently does a supermassive black hole oscillate around a stellar core because of gravitational wave recoil or a delay in binary formation? As the immediate precursor of massive black hole binaries, studies of kiloparsec-scale galaxy mergers will also have important implications for low-frequency gravitational wave experiments.

Students:

This grant has been primarily used to support two graduate students (A. Gross and J. Steffen) and nine undergraduate students (J. Isbell in particular, now pursuing a PhD at the MPIA). Both graduate students obtained their M.S. degrees (with thesis) and passed the PhD comprehensive exams during the funding period and are scheduled to defend their Ph.D. in Spring 2022. Four of the nine undergraduate students are now in astronomy graduate schools.

Intellectual Merit:

The Iowa team has made major contributions in 13 peer-reviewed papers (out of 30 papers in total). The ones closely related to the project are: (1) the radio selection of a kpc-scale binary AGN sample and our follow-up studies with the VLA, the VLBI, and Chandra (Fu+15a, Fu+15b, Bondi+16, Gross+19), (2) detailed measurements of correlated AGN activities and enhanced star-formation in close galaxy pairs (Steffen+21, Fu+18), (3) the recognition of low-z Lyman-alpha blobs as AGN ionization echoes (Schirmer16), and (4) the discovery of an H-alpha blob associated with a dry galaxy merger in MaNGA (Lin+17). Other accomplishments include:(1) the discovery of metal-poor cool gas accretion streams in early hot massive halos (Fu+16, Fu+17, Fu+21),(2) flat rotation curves found in a high-redshift starburst merger through tilted-ring modeling of ALMA data (Xue+18}, and (3) the first measurement of the evolution of molecular gas fraction with the Tully-Fisher relation (Isbell+18b).

Broader Impacts:

The PI recruited nine undergraduate students in the upper-level Astrophysics course to build the first augmented reality (AR) sandbox to demonstrate gravitational dynamics. The students worked in parallel in three teams -- hardware, algorithm, and interface. The development took a solid 1.5 years. The completed product is presented in the attached figure and on a dedicated website hosted by the University (http://astro.physics.uiowa.edu/gravbox/). The python software is made publicly available on GitHub. On behalf of the group, the lead student gave an oral presentation at the 2018 AAS winter meeting (Isbell+18a). Since completion, gravbox has been shown to the public in a physics demonstration show and the Iowa City STEM festival. Over a thousand people showed up to these events, including hundreds of K-12 students. Multiple groups have contacted us expressing interests in reproducing gravbox in their local setting. With the help from our students, the first external realization of gravbox was completed in May 2018 by the Canadian Particle Astrophysics Research Centre (CPARC) at the Queens' University in Kingston, Ontario.
